answers.a: Yes—E903 carnauba wax is an approved food glazing/coating agent and is considered safe at typical food levels; it’s essentially inert and passes through the body undigested.
Yes—it's a plant-derived wax from the leaves of the carnauba palm and is generally considered vegan.

answers.q: what is carnauba wax in food
answers.a: It’s a plant wax used as a glazing/coating agent to add shine, prevent sticking, and reduce moisture loss on products like candies, chewing gum, chocolate, and some fruits.

answers.q: where does carnauba wax come from
answers.a: It comes from the leaves of the carnauba palm (Copernicia prunifera) native to northeastern Brazil; the dried leaves are beaten to release the wax, which is then refined.

answers.q: how long does carnauba wax last
answers.a: The wax itself is very stable and can be stored for years if kept cool and dry; on foods, the thin coating lasts through the product’s normal shelf life but doesn’t significantly extend it.
